Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Engineering Entrepreneurship Education (E3) - A Multidisciplinary, Entrepreneurial Research Experience for Undergraduates

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Connecticut entitled, Engineering Entrepreneurship Education (E3)-A Multidisciplinary, Entrepreneurial Research Experience for Undergraduates, will create novel research experiences for a talented and diverse group of undergraduate students from traditionally underrepresented populations, with limited access to STEM research opportunities. The National Academy of Engineering reports that entrepreneurship is one of the most critical skills to be taught to engineering undergraduates. The proposed REU addresses this need by giving students the opportunity to work on research projects with commercial potential while simultaneously introducing them to challenges associated with bringing new technologies to market. The program offers entrepreneurship, communication, idea generation, salesmanship, and creativity opportunities to encourage students to pursue their own creative and entrepreneurial endeavors in the future. Students with this experience can serve as force multipliers, encouraging and engaging other students or individuals to also engage in creative and entrepreneurial enterprises developing the entrepreneurial mindset necessary to support a vibrant, technology-based economy. To extend the benefits of entrepreneurial engineering training to disadvantaged populations, the site has established a recruitment partnership with Connecticut State Colleges and Universities (CSCU) to meet ambitious goals for minority participation. Opening avenues to minority students to achieve entrepreneurial competence will translate to greater economic opportunities within their home institutions.

Over a three year period, this REU Site program will engage undergraduate students in a 10-week intensive, summer research experience focused on projects identified as having a high potential for translation to commercial projects and which encourage cross-disciplinary discussions and stimulate creativity. The research program will be complemented by a formal engineering entrepreneurship program that will focus on the creative process, idea generation, prototyping, and the realities of starting a business. Students will develop communication skills through required presentations to the REU cohort, their faculty mentors, and entrepreneurs. This REU program translates the model used by a successful graduate course in entrepreneurship at the University of Connecticut to a context appropriate for undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Entrepreneurial Research Experience for Undergraduates (E-REU) program served 10 students per year for three years, providing them with a cutting edge and translational research experience in a faculty laboratory at the University of Connecticut. The research projects were selected specifically because of their highly applied nature and potential for commercialization. In parallel to their research, the students also participated in a 10-week structured entrepreneurship program led by a UConn faculty member with significant experience in tech transfer and start-ups. As part of this program, the students gained experience in idea generation, opportunity and risk assessment, business models, intellectual property, market size analysis, business plans, and communicating ideas. Students also had the opportunity to interact with faculty, entrepreneurs, successful start-ups, venture capitalists, and other business leaders. They were able to present their work in authentic environments and receive feedback on both the technical and business aspects of their work. 

 

In terms of intellectual merit, this program contributed to the expanding body of work in entrepreneurial engineering education. Much of entrepreneurial education has focused on impacting students’ knowledge, confidence, and intentionality with regards to entrepreneurial ventures. Our external evaluator for the project surveyed the participating students both pre- and post-participation in the program, and found that, consistent with the literature, an intensive, residential, and experiential program focused on entrepreneurship produced positive gains in students’ knowledge, confidence, and intentionality with regards to undertaking entrepreneurial activities. Students also demonstrated positive gains in their engineering and communication skills as a result of their participation in the program.

 

In terms of broader impacts, this REU program attracted students from diverse demographics from across the United States. These students return to their home institutions with the knowledge gained from this experience, and will hopefully use it to engage in solving some of society’s most pressing challenges and problems in creative and unique ways, becoming ambassadors for creative and entrepreneurial thinking and problem solving. More locally, this REU served as an important bridge between UConn and the CT community college system, providing research experiences for community college students seeking to transfer to a four-year engineering program after completing their two-year program.
